title: Vlatko Marković
text:
Vladimir "Vlatko" Marković (; 1 January 1937 – 23 September 2013) was a Croatian professional <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> and player who served as the president of the <a href="Croatian%20Football%20Federation">Croatian Football Federation</a> from 1998 to 2012.
Playing career.
Club.
He played for: <a href="NK%20Iskra">Iskra</a> (Bugojno), <a href="NK%20%C4%8Celik%20Zenica">Čelik</a> (<a href="Zenica">Zenica</a>), <a href="Dinamo%20Zagreb">Dinamo</a> (<a href="Zagreb">Zagreb</a>), <a href="Wiener%20SC">Wiener SC</a> (<a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>).
International.
From 1958 until 1959 he played three matches for <a href="Yugoslavia%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Yugoslavia national under-21 football team</a>, and from 7 May 1961 (debut against <a href="Hungary%20national%20football%20team">Hungary</a>) until 30 September 1962 (final game against <a href="West%20Germany%20national%20football%20team">West Germany</a>) he played in <a href="Defender%20%28football%29">defense</a> for <a href="Yugoslavia%20national%20football%20team">Yugoslavia</a> and scored one <a href="own%20goal">own goal</a> in 16 matches. He played in all matches on <a href="1962%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1962 FIFA World Cup</a> when Yugoslavia finished 4th.
Managerial career.
After he finished his playing career, he coached <a href="NK%20Zagreb">Zagreb</a> (Zagreb), <a href="Standard%20de%20Li%C3%A8ge">Standard de Liège</a> (<a href="Li%C3%A8ge">Liège</a>), <a href="OGC%20Nice">OGC Nice</a> (<a href="Nice">Nice</a>), <a href="Hajduk%20Split">Hajduk</a> (<a href="Split%20%28city%29">Split</a>) and <a href="Dinamo%20Zagreb">Dinamo</a> (Zagreb). With Dinamo he won <a href="Yugoslav%20Cup">Yugoslav Cup</a> in 1980.
From 1974 to 1978 he was a <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a> instructor. He also participated in the <a href="FIFA%20World%20Rankings">FIFA Coca-Cola</a>-program.
He was elected president of the Croatian Football Federation on 18 December 1998. He was reelected in 2002 and on 16 December 2006, again with unanimous support. He resigned at 15 May 2012.
Personal life.
In 1945, his uncles died during the <a href="Yugoslav%20death%20march%20of%20Nazi%20collaborators">Yugoslav death march of Nazi collaborators</a>. In <a href="SFRY">SFRY</a>, his father spent over 15 years in prison for possessing illegal firearm.
Views.
In November 2010, Marković spoke out against gay footballers, telling both the Croatian "<a href="Ve%C4%8Dernji%20list">Večernji list</a>" and the Serbian "<a href="Ve%C4%8Dernje%20novosti">Večernje novosti</a>" that, "As long as I'm president [of the Croatian football federation] there will be no gay players. Thank goodness only healthy people play football." He has been reported for the comment to <a href="UEFA">UEFA</a>. In July 2011, in response to his comments, he was charged €10,000 by <a href="UEFA">UEFA</a>.
Death.
He died at Zagreb in 2013. He was 76.
